00018 /**
00019 
00020 @page cvmx_backward CN7XXX backward compatibility support
00021 
00022 Here CN7XXX means, CN78XX, CN73XX, CNF75XX that use OCTEON III packet IO blocks.
00023 
00024  - @ref cvmx_compat_limitations
00025  - @ref cvmx_feat_unsupp
00026  - @ref cvmx_pko_bc
00027  - @ref cvmx_sso_bc
00028  - @ref cvmx_fpa_bc
00029  - @ref cvmx_wqe_bc
00030  - @ref cvmx_fau_bc
00031 
00032 @section cvmx_compat_limitations Compatibility mode limitations
00033 
00034 cvmx_cmd_queue_length()  should not be called directly for PKO queues.
00035 use cvmx_pko_queue_pend_count() instead for PKO queues
00036 
00037 Legacy SE applications are confined to using resources located on the 
00038 same node as the executing core.
00039 
00040 @section cvmx_feat_unsupp Features not supported
00041 Backpressure is not supported in legacy mode.
00042 
00043 @section cvmx_pko_bc PKO Backward Compatibility
00044 The CN7XXX does not make any use of PKO internal ports, and therefore all
00045 functions that refer to "pko_port" are made to use "IPD port" to take its 
00046 place. Also note that cvmx_pko_ipd2pko() and related functions that relate 
00047 to "PKO internal ports" are now obsolete, and maintained solely for 
00048 backward-compatibility, therefore should not be used in new applications.
00049 
00050 pko_get_base_queue(), pko_get_num_queues() return the Descriptor Queue range
00051 assigned to the IPD port passed as argument. Note that with the current helper
00052 configuration, these queues are in order of actual priority, highest to lowest.
00053 
00054 Legacy PKO packet transmission functions support the use of legacy PKO command
00055 and buffer pointer structure on the CN78XX and new Octeon III models.
00056 The legacy buffer pointer "pool" field is supported, in that it is
00057 each buffer can be released to a different aura if required.
00058 The legacy structures are translated to CN7XXX native data structures
00059 which incurrs some overhead, therefore for performance-sensitive applications,
00060 the new native Octeon3 API is strongly recommended.
00061 
00062 There are a few limitations on legacy PKO transmission function:
00063 The PTP bit in the 3rd command word is not supported, it can not
00064 be readily distinguished from an extension of a physical address.
00065 The software-emulated FAU is supported via the legacy PKO transmit
00066 function, but it does not support 16-bit counters, as these are
00067 not supported by PKO3 hardware.
00068 
00069 cvmx_pko_get_port_status() retreives the CN7XXX PKO counters for total
00070 octets and packets transmitted on a given Descriptor Queue, but it does
00071 not retreive other counters (such as dropped packets).
00072 A more complete set of statistics counter is implemented by the BGX
00073 module, although these counters are per interface port.
00074 
00075 The DQ range per IPD port is contigous, so as not to sacrifice performance.
00076 This means that all DQs (both Static and WRR priority) must be allocated
00077 all at once. PKO port-to-queue translation is a per-node BSS array, for node-local
00078 searches to be the fastest. 
00079 
00080 @section cvmx_sso_bc SSO considerations
00081 The major change to the SSO is the change in the nature of group ids. 
00082 Previous chips had 8 priorities with 16 groups each. The CN78XX has 256 
00083 groups (or 64 groups on CN73xx/CNF75xx), with configurable priority levels,
00084 allowing greater flexibility. To avoid confusion, function arguments that
00085 refer to the new extended group numbering scheme are named "xgrp", whereas
00086 argument named "group" or "grp" are treated in a backward-compatible fashion,
00087 according to the following convention: the 3 lowest bits are designated to
00088 represent the 'qos" value, and by default all 256 groups will be configured
00089 to mimic the functionality found in older models, and organized in set of 8 
00090 "xgrp"s, where e.g. each set always assigned a processor core together.
00091 
00092 @section cvmx_fpa_bc FPA considerations
00093 The first 8 auras are reserved to represent the 8 legacy buffer pools,
00094 so that the legacy pool number is translated into a node-local aura number
00095 one-to-one. Also the FPA is only supported in Natural Alignment mode when using
00096 the legacy api.
00097 
00098 For details about a CN7XXX-specific API additions that enable the use
00099 of new features introduced, please see 'CN7XXX native api reference' section
00100 in the Octeon Software Development Kit document and 'cvmx-fpa3.h" file under
00101 executive directory.
00102 
00103 @section cvmx_wqe_bc WQE considerations
00104 The most critical hardware-controlled data structure that has dramatically 
00105 changed in the CN7XXX is the Work Queue Entry, specifically in the way it 
00106 is filled in by the PKI and delivered to the application from the cvmx_get_work() 
00107 function. Because of these changes, it is no longer recommended to inspect 
00108 packets by simply dereferencing the WQE pointer, but instead application 
00109 developers are advised to take advantage of the new accessor functions now 
00110 provided in executive/cvmx-wqe.h. 
00111 This is the most important category of changes for an application to implement 
00112 if it intends to support CN78XX and future devices. It is permissible for 
00113 applications that prefer to handle the SoC model dependencies by themselves 
00114 to access the model-specific members of the WQE data structure, but 
00115 applications must themselves ensure the correct member fields are accessed 
00116 as appropriate for the target hardware. Most WQE accessor functions are simple 
00117 and self-explanatory, as they are named for the field they intend to access, 
00118 but certain critical accessor routines handle functionality which is 
00119 considerably more complex on the CN7XXX and will be documented here.
00120 
00121 cvmx_buf_ptr_t cvmx_wqe_get_packet_ptr(cvmx_wqe_t *work)
00122 
00123 This function is critical for understanding the backwards-compatible packet 
00124 I/O API. This function will return a buffer link pointer compatible with legacy 
00125 models, even when running on the CN7XXX.
00126 
00127 When running on the CN7XXX this function will convert the buffer link pointer 
00128 contained in the work queue entry to the legacy format, compatible with older 
00129 models such that the application may process the packet data without any changes. 
00130 The buffer link pointer also needs to be converted to the legacy format so it 
00131 can be ultimately passed as an argument to the cvmx_pko_send_finish() function 
00132 for transmit. A reserved bit within the WQE is set as a flag indicating this 
00133 conversion has been performed, and to ensure multiple calls will not attempt 
00134 to reconvert the WQE. The conversion of the buffer link pointer imposes several 
00135 limitations on the backward-compatible use of the CN7XXX, and these limitations 
00136 have implications for other subsystems as well.
00137 
00138 1. The legacy buffer link pointer has a 3-bit "pool" field, and for this reason 
00139 a backward-compatible application can only use auras numbered 0-7 (inclusive) 
00140 for any buffers containing packets.
00141 
00142 2. The physical address field of the buffer link pointer is 40-bits wide,
00143 which implies that all buffers used to contain packets
00144 can not store the information of the node where the buffer memory is residing.
00145 The backward-compatible PKO API will however recieve the node information
00146 based on the node number on which the application is running, so that
00147 as long as each SE application is confined to using buffers residing
00148 in the same node that it runs on, the buffers should get transmitted.
00149 Beware however when accessing packet data, because translating the
00150 partial physical address to an XKPHYS virtual address for a buffer
00151 that stored on non-zero node memory will result in an incorrect translation.
00152 For this reason, it is recommended that applications that are taking
00153 advantage of the backward-compatibility API be deployed only on node 0.
00154 
00155 When this function is invoked on CN68XX and earlier models,
00156 while it returns the buffer link pointer in IPD format, it also performs the
00157 necessary handling of packets that are contained within the WQE itself,
00158 including the handling of "dynamic short" packets, as well as the "NO_WPTR" mode
00159 option supported by the CN68XX. Using this accessor on legacy devices eliminatesi
00160 the need to detect and handle the above-mentioned cases within application code,
00161 and makes the application code simpler and easier to maintain.
00162 
00163 int cvmx_wqe_get_bufs(cvmx_wqe_t *work)
00164 
00165 This function is intended to extract the number of buffers attached to the work 
00166 queue entry. It will, however, also call cvmx_wqe_bufptr() if the work queue 
00167 entry needs to be processed for backwards-compatibility when running on CN7XXX, 
00168 or for processing packets contained within the WQE. For that reason it will 
00169 return at least 1 as the buffer count, and prepares the buffer link pointer 
00170 to the correct address of the packet data even if contained within the WQE.
00171 
00172 void cvmx_wqe_free(cvmx_wqe_t *work)
00173 
00174 This function is not an accessor per se, but a helper that will correctly 
00175 release the memory (if any) that is occupied by the work queue entry to 
00176 the same aura(or pool) it was allocated from. If packet data is contained 
00177 within the WQE however, this call will not free any memory, but will instead 
00178 rely on the PKO to release the buffer upon completion of processing. It is 
00179 advised to use this function instead of calling cvmx_fpa_free() directly as 
00180 it does not require the application to detect if the first packet buffer is 
00181 inside or outside the WQE, and does not need to have separate knowledge of 
00182 which aura/pool the WQE should be released to (ie which aura/pool the PKI 
00183 allocated it from originally). Note that on the CN78XX the WQE and packet 
00184 buffers may be allocated from any of the 1024 (or 64 on CN73xx/CNF75XX)
00185 available auras, therefore for legacy applications the additional logic
00186 required is non-trivial.
00187 
00188 Setting WQEs for two-buffer mode
00189 Function  void cvmx_helper_pki_set_wqe_mode(int node, uint64_t ipd_port, bool pkt_outside_wqe)
00190 sets up wqe mode. To make wqe use a separate buffer from packet data, you will need to 
00191 set mode to 1.
00192 Warning: number of packet buffers needs to be doubled since wqe buffer also comes from 
00193 packet data now. It will consume double the memory.
00194 
00195 @section cvmx_fau_bc FAU considerations
00196 
00197 There is no hardware FAU block in the CN7XXX. For legacy applications the 
00198 api is emulated using atomic writes by both the CPU and PKO block. However, 
00199 the async fau functions are no longer async, and iobdma operations are handled 
00200 as direct atomic operations.
00201 
00202 */
